fields.description:
*The problem:*
Changes to test processes in the code repo require changes to the build plan.
If your development lifecycle allows requires pull-requests and code reviews your changes will need to be tested before they can be merged into the mainstream.
However, to test the changes work correctly you may have to make changes to the build plans  but doing this will affect the existing code and pull requests that are reliant on the original build plan.

*The solution:*
Enable the build plan to be configured from a file within the version control system (in a similar way to Travis).
This will allow developers and testers to make necessary changes to the test process without breaking the process before the changes has been accepted.
fields.summary: Build Plan Config File in VCS

fields.summary: REST API for a plan's notifications including event and recipient data

h3. Summary

Branch builds do not update submodules correctly. On a plan for a {{master}} build, I have a *dmz* branch configured as a Gatekeeper, merging back to master (screenshot attached). Every so often the commit pushed to master will not include a submodule update. Investigating the logs, I can see that submodules are updated after checking out the master branch, but not after merging dmz, resulting in the wrong thing being pushed to master (checkout log pasted below).

We have an explicit submodule update task in our build, which must be working some of the time, since sometimes the submodule does get updated on master, and sometimes it does not.

h3. Workaround

For submodules defined with an absolute path:
 Add a script task to manually execute {{"git submodule update --init --recursive"}} as a build step.

For submodules defined with a relative path, since it won't be present in the git cache we'll need to change the remote:
 Add a script task to manually execute the below as a build step.
{code:java}
git remote set-url origin ${bamboo.planRepository.repositoryUrl}
git submodule sync
git submodule update --init --recursive
git remote remove origin
{code}

fields.description:
At the moment, the automatic termination of EC2 instances will terminate them. It will be a good option to allow users he option to choose whether instances should be terminated or just stopped.

The use case for this is to have improved start up of instances. In situations where the instance has a start up script that installs some additional executable/libraries, the instance takes longer time to fire up.
fields.summary: Add additional option to stop instances not terminate

fields.description:
Summary shows 268 passed. Details shows 268 skipped. 

The tests are all skipped in this particular case and it is correctly showing the test failed.

h3. Update
This is more serious, it is simply showing incorrect results in all cases where there are skipped tests. You can no longer rely on the dashboard to show how many test are successful. In another case is shows 220 passed when in reality, 164 tests passed and 56 tests were skipped.

fields.summary: Support for MariaDB

fields.description: PerconaDB and MariaDB are two flavors of MySQL that are not working the same way as MySQL Community Server. Please make sure the supported version is detailed and Percona and MariaDB are mentioned as unsupported specifically. See the reference for Confluence: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-36474

fields.summary: Support for PerconaDB

fields.description:
Configuring Bamboo builds is really like creating a build script, and right now there is no way for me to comment on how and why I have setup my Bamboo "script" a certain way.

Thus, I wish I could add comments at the Bamboo server level, and to projects, plans, and tasks, about how they were setup. It would be wonderful if the comments or notes could be long and *rich*, like JIRA-style description fields (maybe excepting comments on tasks, which I think would usually be short).

By comments at the server level I mean something like a menu or some link on the home page (maybe under the "?" menu), where an admin would click to see a page with notes on the overall project and plan configuration.

On projects, plans, and tasks maybe there would a similar button, link, or maybe a "hover over" control; I'm not sure exactly how or where, but I'm sure you guys can figure it out. ;-)

And of course, this would probably be irrelevant to regular users just looking for build status or artifacts, so the notes would be available only to admin users (or maybe they could be enabled/disabled as an admin would see fit).
fields.summary: Be able to add comments or notes about Bamboo build configuration.

fields.description:
Amazon released it's new VPC endpoints recently: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/new-vpc-endpoint-for-amazon-s3/

Currently these are not supported and if customers switch over they'll lose connectivity to S3 and be unable to kick off EC2 agents among other functionality.
fields.summary: New VPC endpoints for S3 are not supported by Bamboo

fields.description: Currently when an expiry is run all deployment history is lost, as expected. It would be great if this historical data was concatenated to it's own DB table so it can be recalled even after expiries are run or retained in some other way.
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to persist build/deployment history through expiry

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The 'Remote Trigger' in Bamboo is causing only main plans to be triggered, even though commits are made to branches associated to branch plans within that main plan.

Example:

I have the following test project setup:

Main plan with trigger "Repository triggers the build then changes are commited" and selected repository with branch "develop".

Branch plan with trigger "Repository triggers the build then changes are commited" and selected repository with branch "master".

For both repositories selected Bitbucket. (See screenshot for what I mean by that. I will test with Git later).

Now when I commit changes to *master* brach main plan gets triggered instead of Master branch plan. I expect Master branch plan to be triggered.

New commit to develop branch will trigger main branch plan as expected. 

It works well if "Pull the repository for changes" selected.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a repository in BitBucket (and possibly other repositories) with the main and another branch, say test branch.
# Create a plan in Bamboo associated with the main branch and a branch plan within it associated with the 'test' branch
# Add repository to the plan
# Create a 'Remote Trigger' in Bamboo to the repository and a service in Bitbucket, as described [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Repository+triggers+the+build+when+changes+are+committed], so BitBucket triggers the build immediately after commit
# Commit to the 'test' branch

h3. Expected Results
# A build in the branch plan is triggered, as this is the one associated with the 'test' branch

h3. Actual Results
# The main branch is triggered
 

h3.Workaround
# Use repository polling instead
fields.summary: Repository commit trigger will always trigger main build
GET for rest/api/latest/queue resource does not work

fields.description:
Currently deployments can be canceled via the UI. However if the deployment is in the hung middle of a network operation the java process will wait for that to complete before clearing the hung deployment and allowing for more. It would be nice if this was handled more gracefully, ie. if x number of seconds passes without response from the deployment that we've tried to cancel remove it from the queue so it doesn't block other operations.

The only workaround now is to restart Bamboo and this is not an option in many high availability, high use environments.
fields.summary: Bamboo should handle hung deployments more gracefully

fields.description:
I have plans that are set up as follows:
  An automated stage that is triggered when a commit happens.  It builds snapshots
  A manual stage that builds releases.

Each plan has dependencies set up, so it causes the next component to build.

I would like to be able to set up the manual stage to either
1) Force all stages, including manual, of a dependency to execute
2) Force specific stages, including manual, of a dependency to execute

Obviously, I want to use the plan's existing dependencies, I do not wish to set up dependencies twice.

I am aware that I can do this via the REST API in theory, but dependency/*/child returns the message 'not implemented yet'.  It would be much more convenient to have this as an option in the user interface.
fields.summary: Force manual stages of a dependency to run

fields.description:
Add a option for Deploy Triggers to execute only when there is a newer build available.

There is only 2 type of triggers in Bamboo and not enough customization on the "when" to deploy. 

Here we use the Schedule Trigger,  but often the build is Deploy even if there is no change during the day.
fields.summary: Add a Option on Deploy Triggers to execute only when there is a newer build

fields.description:
Charts are not visible, even if data range is from more than one day (btw: even for one day a chart shall be visible - shall contain a message "insufficient data range"). Currently, this section is completely empty. 

Affects: Bamboo 5.9 (standalone and Cloud)

*Workaround:* use "Reports > Reports" to generate Clover's charts.
fields.summary: The "History charts" section is empty on the "Clover" tab

fields.description:
PHPUnit (version till 4.6.6) can export coverage data in nearly Clover-XML compatible format. "Nearly", because:
 * the <metrics> tag is defined at the end of the enclosing tag (which is fine, actually, but not optimal as Clover must read entire XML file instead of just a beginning)
 * in case when a *.php file has no namespace defined, it's being written as <file> tag directly under the <project> or <testproject> (instead of <package name="default-pkg">). 

Bamboo Clover Plugin does not expect the <file> tag outside the <package> tag, as a consequence:

{code:xml}
<coverage>
  <project>
    <file>
      <metrics/>  <!-- clover takes this -->
    </file>
    <package>
       <file>
         <metrics/>
       </file>
     </package>
     <metrics/> <!-- but should take this -->
  </project>
</coverage>
{code}

*Fix:* make plugin more resilient against deviations from Clover's XML file format.
fields.summary: Bamboo Clover Plugin parses XML created by PHPUnit incorrectly

fields.description:
In the bamboo build dashboard, the text shown when code is being checked out is:
"Updating source code to latest"

"Updating source code" or "Getting source code" would be sufficient and the word "latest" tells me nothing.  After the git clone is done, do I still have the latest code, or has another commit happened in the interim?  If I clone from a branch, is that "latest" or is another branch later?  What version is "latest" anyway?

A more accurate message would show the the actual commit SHA1 instead of the vague "latest", but just removing the text "latest" would be better.
fields.summary: Remove "latest" from build dashboard status message

fields.description:
after fixing https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/browse/BUILDENG-8059 we've got a lot of complaints about bamboo requiring plan names and description to avoid certain characters ( [, ], {, }, <, >, :, @, /, &, %, \, !, |, #, $, *, ; or ~)

I'm wondering if this limitation is really necessary and if the problem (XSS) shouldn't be tackled on the rendering side of things, instead of limiting people from using these characters..
fields.summary: investigate if current validation on plan name/description is necessary

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Add a new linked repository (Administration > Build Resources > Linked Repositories), of any type.
# Click the 'X' to delete it.
# Hit Confirm.

h3. Expected results
The repository is deleted.

h3. Actual results
The UI gives an error: "An unexpected error has occurred: Not Found" and Bamboo's logs contain this:

{code:none}
2015-05-06 10:03:32,484 WARN [TP-Processor1] [ServletUrlRenderer] No configuration found for the specified action: 'deleteGlobalRepository' in namespace: '/admin/'. Form action defaulting to 'action' attribute's literal value.
2015-05-06 10:03:32,513 WARN [TP-Processor1] [ServletUrlRenderer] No configuration found for the specified action: 'deleteGlobalRepository' in namespace: '/admin/'. Form action defaulting to 'action' attribute's literal value.
{code}
fields.summary: Unable to deleted linked repositories in 5.9-OD-01

fields.description:
Please, update [Integrating Bamboo with LDAP|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+LDAP] as the majority of clients experience difficulties on settings up Active Directory in Bamboo based on the documentation provided. 

In attempt on reducing the amount of support tickets raised regarding on LDAP, the following [How to set up LDAP in Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/How+to+set+up+LDAP+in+Bamboo] has been created to surpass the following information:
* *how to set up your Active Directory (LDAP) in "{{atlassian-user-custom.xml}}"*
_The official documentation does not cover the creation of "{{atlassian-user-custom.xml}}" when setting up Active Directory in Bamboo. This file is useful incase someone updates the "{{User repositories}}" method under "{{Bamboo administration >> Security}}" by mistake and bring the instance down, which will imply on losing the LDAP configuration. By having an "{{atlassian-user-custom.xml}}" file, a copy to the LDAP set up will be keep and Bamboo searches for this file and copy its content to "{{atlassian-user.xml}}" when "{{Custom user repository}}" option is selected._
* *how to validate "atlassian-user-custom.xml" using* [Paddle|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Testing+LDAP+or+Active+Directory+connectivity+with+Paddle]
_An important point is how to make sure Bamboo is set up correctly and the "{{users}}" and "{{groups}}" from your LDAP configuration is retrieving the correct information. I would be very helpful mentioning [Testing LDAP or Active Directory connectivity with Paddle|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Testing+LDAP+or+Active+Directory+connectivity+with+Paddle] KB as a resource for testing._
* *how to integrate "atlassian-user-custom.xml" with Bamboo*

As a workaround, a [comment|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+LDAP?focusedCommentId=738361651&#comment-738361651] to the official documentation [Integrating Bamboo with LDAP|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+LDAP] has been made.
fields.summary: Documentation - Integrating Bamboo with LDAP

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce*
# Start Child Plan build
# Parent Plan starts while Child Plan build is currently running.  

*Actual Result*
Parent Plan cannot trigger Child plan build. Because the Child Plan build is already running when Parent Plan starts. As this result, the child plan build does not contain the latest artifacts of his Parent Plan.

*Expected Result*
Parent Plan should queue the child plan again, after the Child Plan triggered by "changes are committed" completed. As this result, the child plan can contain the latest artifacts of his Parent Plan.
fields.summary: Parent plan doesn't queue child plan build if child is already running

fields.description:
The Xunit xml report has a treasure trove of data for timing data. To know how long each test runs is important data for the task of reducing build times. It is this data that provides the informed answer for the test automation folks.

Bamboo does so easily let us find this data.

In the Build Results data, I expect to sort the test-cases in one of 3 ways:
1) execution order (how it is now, by default)
2) alphabetical name (just to find stuff if I need to by name)
3) test duration (for this specific work of quickening test suites)

When it divides tests into pages, I expect my page number to be consistent when I reorder,  and find the range of tests 50-100 (on page 2 for example) for the newly-selected order. This requirement is not very important. The real gold is just being able to find the long-running tests.

I found there was a previous request in BAM-532 to find longest-running-tests. This sounds great! It sounds like it was done. But where is it in the Bamboo interface? I cannot find it. Maybe all I'm asking for is directions to it. Let me know if so.
fields.summary: No link to reach long-running test cases page

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo agent does not close itself if it exceeds the max failed invocations value.
It falls into a pause mode in Windows requesting user to "Press Any Key to continue"
This makes tracking the application status difficult. If the process is killed immediately, process monitor would be able to track it and perform necessary actions after closing.
fields.summary: Automatically close Bamboo Agent application after breaching max_failed_invocations

fields.description:
When Bamboo runs a build, we export capabilities out to the command as environment variables so that the build will have access to them. 

In large and complex environments with larger customers, this can result in a huge number of additional arguments being passed to the command line. 

An improvement for larger customers would be to be able to limit the variables that are exported, possibly with a regex, or to identify what may actually be called in the external environment (not always obvious.) and just export those.
fields.summary: Ability to select or disable environment variables passed to external builds

fields.description:
When running a build, Bamboo provides several variables that can be access by "$\{bamboo.sth\}" based on the [Bamboo Variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+variables] documentation.

The environment variables available to your job can be seen by adding a Script task with:
{noformat}
# if Windows, uncomment the following line by removing the hash (#) character
#set

# if Linux, uncomment the following line by removing the hash (#) character
#env
{noformat}
There are variables that are not exposed to the notification templates. An example would be a variable that holds the Build Working Directory (i.e.: $\{bamboo.working.directory\}).

Please, update the documentation by providing with a list of variables that are available to the notification templates.
fields.summary: Expose build environment variables to notification templates
Bamboo gadgets are not working since upgrade to 5.9

fields.description:
+PROBLEM+
When a new branch is created in a repo where include filters are specified, all build plans using the linked repo with include filters that *do not* match the change will still run.

+TO REPRODUCE+
# Create 1 repo in Stash named say, myrepo
# Create 2 linked repos from the same Stash repo using different non-overlapping include filter, a/.* and b/.*
# Create 2 build plans with branch builds enabled, one using each Linked Repo. say, BP-A and BP-B
# Clone myrepo
# Create a new branch 
# Commit a change, say create a/a.txt and commit this
# Push to remote repo
# BP-A and BP-B will both build
# Repeat the process, say update a/a.txt and push this change
# Only BP-A will now build

+IMPACT+
We have a dev team that wants to use a single monolithinc repo for a bunch of components and this is causing builds to kick off uncecessarily that causes delays in feedback and delays in resolving commit builds and branch inconsistency on a very regular basis directly impacting developers time due to investigation and confusion.
fields.summary: Branch builds do not honor Linked Repos includes/excludes on branch creation

fields.description:
This is currently a manual step. Whenever a deployment fails the only way of rolling back is by going to {{Deploy}} menu, selecting {{All Deployment Projects}} and clicking in the environment name, where it shows a list of releases deployed in that environment and an option to rollback to one of those.

This process could be automated by rolling back automatically to the previous successful deployment if the current deployment fails.
fields.summary: Automatically rollback to previous successful deployment if the current fails

fields.description:
Hi,

the links to the builds in Bamboo are broken, when you switched tabs before (for example you go from "Build summary" to "Tests" or "Logs").

Good link:
http://domain:port/bamboo/build/result/gotoBuildResult.action?buildKey=QCP-QCPDEVJEE6&buildNumber=138&returnUrl=%2Fbrowse%2FQCP-QCPDEVJEE6-137
Bad link after switching tabs:
http://domain:port/bamboo/build/result/gotoBuildResult.action?buildKey=QCP-QCPDEVJEE6&buildNumber=138&returnUrl=bamboo%2Fbrowse%2FQCP-QCPDEVJEE6-137%2Ftest

So the difference is: returnUrl=bamboo which is added after switching tabs. The link leads to 404 then.
fields.summary: Bamboo links to builds are broken, after switching tabs

fields.description:
To reproduce: Edit a plan and select the Notifications tab. Click "Add notification" and select "Stash" as the notification type

Actual: You'll get a pop-up warning, screenshot attached. "For Stash to receive this notification an Application Link of Basic Auth is needed between the two systems."

And, indeed, if you use an OAuth-based App Link, the notification will fail.

Expected: Support OAuth app links as well/instead.

Basic Auth is "not recommended." https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/Application+Links+Troubleshooting+Guide And per BAM-15892 it's not possible to set up a Basic Auth AppLink in Bamboo Cloud.
fields.summary: Support Stash notifications via OAuth, not just Basic Auth

fields.description:
Currently every User can see all created Projects when creating a new Plan.

This exposes, probably private/unreleased, Projects of other users.

There should be a permission for Projects like the ones for Plans, or the Project should first be shown when theres at least one Plan in it where the user has permissions for it.
fields.summary: Add Permissions to Projects

fields.description:
Because this configuration is not available for end users, enabling legacy Stash support for repos is not possible to integrate Bamboo Cloud with Stash as an alternative while BAM-15027 is not solved.

For instance:

!Linked_Repo_Legacy.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Allow end users to configure Basic Auth on Cloud

fields.description:
Due to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-12228, the Stash integration functionality available in Bamboo Server is disabled in Bamboo cloud.  This means that some Bamboo-Stash integration features, such as notifications of build statuses, commit information in Bamboo, and repository triggering are unavailable.

!Linked_Repo_Legacy.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: You can't integrate Bamboo Cloud with Stash Server

fields.description:
When JUnit parser finds the tests.xml but is unable to parse the results, the task is still successful and so is the build but test results weren't checked.

The task log displays: "Failed to parse test result file ..."

A test could be failing but since no results are parsed, the true correctness of the test results cannot be guaranteed. The build should be marked as failed and a message should be displayed to correct the situation (as suggested in [BAM-15321|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15321])
fields.summary: Build should fail if JUnit Parser encounters errors parsing the test results

fields.description:
On the build activity page I see plenty of "No agent can build this job" messages - although I don't know what this actually means - is something wrong with my build? Is it just being queued and nothing's available? Have I missed some configuration? A tooltip or _anything_ would be useful to help users understand all this redness :)

Also, when I go to the build itself (which is meant to be doing the release), it just says it's being queued. However, rather than being listed as "Queued" on the build activity page it has this "No agent can build this job" message - some consistency here would be good too.
fields.summary: Let user know what "No agent can build this job" actually means

fields.description:
Linux scripts like start-bamboo.sh and stop-bamboo.sh need a hash-bang line at the top to be properly understood to be executed.

As a tcsh user, I cannot run those scripts directly unless I add "sh" to my commandline or add "#!/bin/sh" to the first line of the script.

Here's my proof:
[twm@mohr bamboo-home]# ../atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/bin/stop-bamboo.sh 
PRG=../atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/bin/stop-bamboo.sh: Command not found.
PRG: Undefined variable.

# (it tries to interpret the script with tcsh)

... and after I edit the script:
[twm@mohr bamboo-home]# vim ../atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/bin/stop-bamboo.sh
[twm@mohr bamboo-home]# ../atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/bin/stop-bamboo.sh

Bamboo Standalone Edition
   Version : 5.8.1
                  
Detecting JVM PermGen support...
PermGen switch is supported. Setting to 256m

If you encounter issues starting or stopping Bamboo Server, please see the Troubleshooting guide at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Installing+and+upgrading+Bamboo

Using CATALINA_BASE:   /ci/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1
Using CATALINA_HOME:   /ci/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1
Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /ci/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/temp
Using JRE_HOME:        /usr
Using CLASSPATH:       /ci/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/bin/bootstrap.jar:/ci/bamboo/atlassian-bamboo-5.8.1/bin/tomcat-juli.jar
fields.summary: start-bamboo.sh and stop-bamboo.sh missing hash-bang at beginning of scripts

fields.description:
JIRA's Build & Release functionality was implemented when Bamboo didn't have Deployment Projects yet.
It mimicked some of the functionality needed for deployment.
Nowadays all deployment related things are supposed to be done in Deployment Projects.
However, it's currently not possible to Build & Release a Deployment Project.
fields.summary: JIRA Build & Release a Deployment Project

fields.description: Currently, Bamboo provides support of shared credentials to git repositories but not to Mercurial repositories under "{{Bamboo administration >> Build resources >> Shared credentials}}". Please, extend this feature.
fields.summary: Enable shared credentials for Mercurial repositories

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo Rest API does not provide REST resource for linked JIRA issues as Discussed in this Answers Post:
- https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/13409880/how-do-i-get-the-linked-jira-issue-for-a-bamboo-test-with-the-rest-api

It would be beneficial to users to expand on the functionality of Bamboo Rest calls to include linked JIRA issue

Fallback solution would be to configure Bamboo so that linking a test failure to a JIRA issue adds the issue to the issues linked to the build. As currently linking an issue to a build is a manual process for each build, and build failure.
fields.summary: Enhance Bamboo's REST API to add a child tag to a test's result that includes any linked JIRA issue

fields.description:
MSBuild throws the following error if there is a space in the solution file directory:
{noformat}MSBUILD : error MSB1008: Only one project can be specified.{noformat}

When reading the response file, MSBuild splits the parameter up at the space and treat it as 2 different parameters.

h5. Workaround
Wrap the solution/project directory in *quotes*. 

or 

h6. Remote agents. 
If you're starting agent manually you simply provide {{-Dbamboo.plugin.dotnet.msbuild.useResponseFile=true}} on the command line. If your agent is run as a service then make a change in the {{$BAMBOO_AGENT_HOME/conf/wrapper.conf}} configuration file:
{noformat}
# The Bamboo Agent home configuration file
wrapper.java.additional.1=-Dbamboo.home=/home/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home
wrapper.java.additional.2=-Dbamboo.agent.ignoreServerCertName=false
wrapper.java.additional.3=-Dbamboo.plugin.dotnet.msbuild.useResponseFile=true
{noformat}

h6. Bamboo server
# stop Bamboo
# add {{-Dbamboo.plugin.dotnet.msbuild.useResponseFile=true}} to {{JVM_REQUIRED_ARGS}} in {{$BAMBOO_INSTALL/bin/setenv.sh}}
# start Bamboo
fields.summary: MSBUILD throws "Only one project can be specified" if there is a space in the directory
Build is successful when Maven fails and tests are quarantined

fields.description: A command can easily be added to execute InspectCode but there is no way to visualize the results. Currently our Jenkins build machine does this and I would like to migrate over to Bamboo but without this feature, supporting Stylecop I can't currently justify a commercial solution as a replacement.
fields.summary: Support Stylecop reports to show .NET code quality

{noformat}

I guess this silent failure is due to Bamboo design decision that artifact definitions by default can but do not have to produce any artifacts. I've created a related ticket BAM-15872 to make this behavior configurable/controllable.

But even when artifact definition allows no artifacts to be published, build log should at least include a warning that artifact publishing was attempted but failed.
fields.summary: Artifact Copier can silently fail to publish artifacts

fields.description:
I have a release build plan, and associated deployment project.
Release build plan has an artifact definition.
When I change just name of artifact definition, and go through:

{noformat}
Related deployment projects
This build plan supplies artifacts for the following deployment projects:
{noformat}

to associated deployment project, "Deployment project summary" page opens, and its "Available artifacts" still displays old artifact definition name.

One way to get it to display updated name, is to practically delete old artifact definition and create a new one - then new artifact definition name only will be displayed under "Available artifacts".

Good thing is, that "Artifact download" task for environments defined in deployment project, display updated artifact (definition) name in "Individual artifacts" of "Artifact name" dropdown list.
But even after seeing new artifact name in "Individual artifacts" of "Artifact download" task definition, and returning to deployment project ("Deployment project summary" page) from environment "update tasks" page by clicking on "Back to deployment project" button, "Available artifacts" still displays old artifact definition name.
fields.summary: Artifact definition name change not reflected on "Deployment project summary" page

fields.description:
I have a build plan with artifact definition(s). Build passes even when no artifacts get attached to the build from (any of) artifact definition(s).

{noformat}
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Running post build plugin 'Artifact Copier'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Publishing an artifact: foo
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Finished publishing of artifact Shared artifact: [foo], pattern: [foo] in 0s
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Running post build plugin 'Post Command Agent Runner'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Running post build plugin 'npm Cache Cleanup'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Running post build plugin 'NCover Results Collector'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Running post build plugin 'Clover Results Collector'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Finalising the build...
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Stopping timer.
19-Apr-2015 16:53:44	Build FOO-137 completed.
19-Apr-2015 16:53:45	Running on server: post build plugin 'Clover Delta Calculator'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Running on server: post build plugin 'Build Hanging Detection Configuration'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Running on server: post build plugin 'deploymentResultProcessor'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Running on server: post build plugin 'NCover Results Collector'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Running on server: post build plugin 'Maven Dependencies Postprocessor'
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	All post build plugins have finished
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Generating build results summary...
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Saving build results to disk...
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Indexing build results...
19-Apr-2015 16:53:46	Finished building FOO-137.
{noformat}

"Produced artifacts" paragraph on stage Artifacts tab for this build says
{quote}
There have been no artifacts set up for this job.
{quote}

Imagine a user configuring artifact definition for a build plan, verifying it works for couple of builds, and then after some time realising that it has stopped working, that no artifacts were available for past n builds, while all those past builds have been labeled as successful.

At least allow from artifact definition one to choose what number of artifacts must come out of artifact definition. "Any"/-1 can be default value.
fields.summary: Build with artifact definition passes even when no artifacts get attached

fields.description:
If the contents of the checkout directory is modified, it is cleaned by {{com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.task.InitializeBuild}} before the build begin. 

Bamboo should provide an option for users that do not desire this behavior.
fields.summary: Provide option to disabled clean directory during build initialization

fields.description:
Hi,

A docker pull task would be helpful for many docker workflows.

Right now the docker build task has an option to disable the Docker cache, but then you are building the entire container every build which is rather inefficient which can take up space on your docker registry.

Ideally the way around this is to always do a docker pull of the base image of the container before every build so that Docker has the latest image.  When Bamboo gets to the build task Docker will then see that there is a newer base image and rebuild the whole container only when the base image has been updated.

A typical workflow would be something like this:
  - Pull base image
  - Build a docker container
  - Push latest tag to a docker repository

This same workflow can also be extended for some other use cases.  For example, say I have tested changes on my own machine and pushed them to a "testing" tag in the docker repository.  Then after I have tested them I commit my changes to source control, and a build is kicked off.

The build tasks would be something like this:
  - Pull base image
  - Pull "testing" and latest tag of the image to be built
  - Build container (This is now nearly instantaneous because the "testing" image is already the same set of layers required to build what is now in source control)
  - Push latest tag to a docker repository (This is also almost instantaneous because the registry already has all of the layers required, and is just tagging them)
fields.summary: Add Docker pull task

fields.description:
On 
- [Bamboo upgrade guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+upgrade+guide]

Step "3. Download and install Bamboo as usual"

We should improve the description. If you just write "Exectue the Installation Guide" that's not going to help customers upgrade it. The process is very similar, but we have to get customers to change their {{bamboo.home}} to point to their existing Bamboo home.

For example, see how [Stash Upgrade doc|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+upgrade+guide] approached that on Step 4.

I also missed the pointers to moving {{server.xml}} changes from their old to the new installation. We should include this part on our Bamboo docs. This has brought quite a few Stash upgrades broken to support. I am referring to the following observation we have in the [Stash Upgrade doc|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+upgrade+guide]:
{quote}
h4. 5. Update any custom configurations
If you have made custom changes to the configuration of your existing Stash installation you will have to make those changes for the new installation as well. For example:

- You may have made changes to the port, context path, or the access protocol (in <Stash installation directory>/conf/server.xml).
- You may be running Stash behind a proxy and have modified the Connector element (in <Stash installation directory>/conf/server.xml).
- You may be using 64-bit libraries on Windows instead of the out-of-the-box 32-bit libraries (bin/tomcat7.exe, bin/tcnative-1.dll).
- If you are using MySQL, you'll need to reinstall the driver in the new installation, or copy the previous driver from the old <Stash installation directory>/lib to the new <Stash home directory>/lib.

Do not simply copy the configuration files from your existing <Stash installation directory> to your new <Stash home directory>/shared directory. Carefully review the differences between your customized version and the default version and re-apply your custom changes to the new configuration files to prevent overwriting configuration changes between different versions of Stash.
{quote}
fields.summary: Improve Upgrade Documentation for Bamboo

fields.description: Update: *Steps to Repeat:* On a Bamboo instance using an LDAP directory for authentication... # Attempt to log into Bamboo using a username that is +NOT+ in the LDAP server yet. # Add the username to the LDAP server. # Once the user is synced with Bamboo, it'll be in this funky/bad state where it thinks it's a local user rather than an LDAP user. # Search for the user in Bamboo admin and click on the "*Edit*" link. # OUTCOME: The following error is loaded... {panel}{color:red}Unable to find the user. The username johnsmith may be incorrect.{color}{panel} Bamboo seems to be hitting some kind of race condition with the identification/storing of users as described above. Original reporting: {quote} One of our LDAP user is not able to log into Bamboo. The user is found during a user search in Bamboo Admin, BUT when I select the option to Edit the user, it displays an error stating the following... {color:red}*Unable to find the user. The username user-name may be incorrect.*{color} I found [the following article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/LDAP+-+Users+are+intermittently+unable+to+login], but it does not appear to be the same issue that we're exhibiting as we already have the LDAP Cache enabled in the ehcache file. I've tried removing the user from LDAP, making sure he's removed from Bamboo, and then adding him back to our LDAP server but it did NOT resolve the issue. I also noticed that it's displaying the "*Delete*" link when it finds the user as if it thinks the user is a local user rather than an LDAP user. I tried deleting the user by clicking on the link and it threw an error. It seems like the user record is corrupt in the user cache. Is there any way to manually clear the user cache? {quote}
fields.summary: One of our LDAP user is not able to log into Bamboo. Unable to find the user. The username user-name may be incorrect.

fields.summary: Stash clone URL should be saved as a relative link rather than an absolute link
Grant permission to multiple users simultaneously (UI and/or REST)

fields.description:
At the moment, the deployment project has 2 permissions viz:

# The *view* permission which allows users access to view only on the projects and all environments
# The *Edit* permissions controls who can change the details of the project, related plan and any of the environment configuration. Users with edit permission can also create releases.

Users with the second permission might not be administrators but giving them the second permission will wield them extra privileges of doing some admin level configurations like dedicating agent to an environment

It will be a good idea to have a third permission called *admin* for example that decouples the extra privileges on the edit. Users with edit permission should just be able to change the tasks, add task and other non-admin tasks like adding variables.
fields.summary: decouple deployment project permissions

fields.description:
Bamboo has no hook that would allow a plugin to run code on an agent _before_ any VCS tasks are executed.  See [answer here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/13402873/is-there-a-build-lifecycle-plugin-that-can-execute-code-before-vcs-checkout].

I would like to write a plugin that allows remote agents to call setuid before they execute any tasks in a build.  This would allow Bamboo agents to execute tasks on behalf of many, potentially untrusted users at a large, multi-user site.

There does not appear to be a suitable hook for this in the Bamboo build process.  The Pre-Build Action executes too late in the build process, as it executes _after_ VCS tasks.

I would be willing to contribute code for this, but I have no way of getting in touch with Atlassian developers.  I think a lot of sites would benefit from this.
fields.summary: Pre-checkout build lifecycle plugin

fields.description:
OBRs are add-ons which bundle their dependencies such that the dependencies get installed alongside the main add-on jar. UPM was able to properly install OBRs in Bamboo 5.7.2 however it is broken in Bamboo 5.8.1. I didn't try in Bamboo 5.8.0.
Debugging into the UPM code it appears that {{org.osgi.service.obr.Resolver#getRequiredResources()}} returns an empty list where it used to return a list of dependencies. UPM also utilizes {{org.osgi.service.obr.Resolver#getOptionalResources()}} however I'm not sure if that is also broken.
I'm marking this bug as critical because there are many Bamboo Paid via Atlassian add-ons which are distributed as OBRs and this essentially means that they cannot be installed until this is fixed. (Complete list of Bamboo PvA add-ons: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/app/bamboo/top-grossing?cost=marketplace)
fields.summary: OBR installation is broken in Bamboo 5.8.x

fields.description:
Currently, the default behaviour of the _Build Summary_ page is to show all *New Failures* expanded. If you wish to have them collapsed, you must click the {{Collapse all}} button. It would be nice to have the ability to configure the *default behaviour* so you can choose if you want all of them expanded or collapsed when accessing the page.

The default is to show all of the new failures expanded:

!default-expanded.png|thumbnail!

However, it would be good to have the ability to choose if you want to have them all collapsed (always):

!request-default-collapsed.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Ability to change default behaviour (expand/collapse) when viewing New Failures on Build Summary page

fields.description:
In case when user runs "mvn clover2:setup install", JARs containing instrumented code will be installed into ~/.m2 local cache. It may cause NoClassDefFoundError in case when such JAR is picked in another build in which Clover is not enabled. 

Similarly, when user runs "mvn clover2:setup deploy", instrumented JARs will be deployed to a repository. 

Clover should allow to protect users from polluting their repositories.

This repository pollution protection feature will be enabled by default for builds where automatic Clover integration is used. In case of manual Clover integration, user can enable this protection by the -Dmaven.clover.repositoryPollutionProtection=true flag.
fields.summary: Protect repositories from being polluted by code instrumented by Clover

fields.description:
$BAMBOO_INST/scripts/lib/jsvn.bat sets SVNKIT_VER=1.8.5 but  $BAMBOO_INST/scripts/lib only includes svnkit-1.7.6.jar.

Running jsvn.bat will return:
Error: Could not find or load main class org.tmatesoft.svn.cli.SVN

The issue can be worked around by making svnkit-1.8.5.jar available, but this should be included by default
fields.summary: jsvn.bat refers to 1.8.5 but only svnkit-1.7.6.jar bundled

fields.description:
When reviewing test results for a build, it's not possible to view the last piece of the log without having to open the entire error log. Typically, it says at the end "(X more lines...)," for example.

!bamboo-issue-example.png!

Occasionally, the most important part of the test results are at the bottom, not at the top. The current logic hides most of the test failures, because it trims off the bottom, not the top.

It would be nice to have the ability to either see all output or a customizable number of lines to show (to truncate the output at a much higher # of lines) or truncate with the tail showing, not the head.
fields.summary: Ability to change the piece of the log that gets truncated on Test results

USE [master]

ALTER DATABASE [bambooM1] SET SINGLE_USER WITH ROLLBACK IMMEDIATE 
ALTER DATABASE [bambooM1] SET READ_COMMITTED_SNAPSHOT ON WITH NO_WAIT
ALTER DATABASE [bambooM1] COLLATE Latin1_General_CS_AS
ALTER DATABASE [bambooM1] SET MULTI_USER
GO
{code}
The lack of those settings can cause EXPIRY to cause the Bamboo service to hang, for example.

Please, check if the collation/isolation in the upgrade task and refuse to start if they are incorrect.
fields.summary: Misconfigured SQL Server causes severe problems in Bamboo

fields.description:

	email = Smaiyaki@atlassian.com

com.atlassian.bamboo.author
com.atlassian.bamboo.notification

com.sun.mail
com.atlassian.bamboo.mail

fields.description:
h6. Bamboo on Cloud

# add a new repository
# select "{{Git}}" as "{{Repository host}}"
# paste in the SSH git URL into the "{{Repository URL}}" field
!bamboo.linkedRepository.gitGitHub.png|thumbnail!

	<buildDate>2015-03-02T18:28:53.000-03:00</buildDate>

</info>
{code}

{color:red} This issue does not happen on Bamboo v5.8.1 behind the firewall{color}
fields.summary: SSH' transport protocol is not supported.

fields.description:
This feature will be particularly useful in situations where users will want to notify various services like the speedcurve or the newrelic after succesful deployment to environments. This feaature can be designed in such a way that it can run a set of task after a successful run of the deployment environment OR after the successful run of all the environments in a deployment projects. For the second aspect, it means we should have a mechanism to trigger  the deployment of the whole project rather than just the environment.

At the moment, because of the avialability of this [feature|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15474], we are able to workaround this issue by piping all the environments to trigger each other with the last environment having a task to do the notification. The downside is that the environments can not be run in parallel and a build failure on one environment will affect the whole deployment
fields.summary: Add a post deployment task

fields.description:
Some customers have a requirement to download the shared artifact from a specific build, rather than form the latest build, for various workflow reasons. 

While it is possible to provide several alternate approaches, such as passing between multiple stages, the ability to select the results from a specific built in the UI would be beneficial.
fields.summary: Download shared artifact from specific build

fields.description:
Currently it's only possible to set the "Idle agent shutdown delay" time.
There would be a good safe measure to have the ability to set a total running time for an agent for it to be shutdown after this running time limit is reached.
fields.summary: Automatic shutdown running agents

fields.description:
In regards to this KB
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Can%27t+delete+or+create+AppLink

Bamboo should check this entry and validate its contents before continuing. 
We were affected by this by having this entry as "<currentApplication />", which caused the problem in that KB. 

Bamboo should check this before using it to prevent this problem
fields.summary: Validate CurrentApplication config entry on startup
Cucumber test results causing OutOfMemory issues in Bamboo

fields.description:
When setting Next Release pattern in Release versioning, if there are 2 periods/decimal points, the second one is replaced with a hyphen. For example, if the pattern resolves to

    release-1.2.3

it is replaced with 

    release-1.2-3

The resolved version should be left as is. This does not seem to be restricted by any limitation in Bamboo, as renaming the release to what was intended works just fine.
fields.summary: second decimal point replaced with hyphen in release version

fields.description:
This bug report was also created under the Stash project.  I didn't know if the actual issue originated from Bamboo or Stash (STASH-7271).

I'm a Stash (3.7.1) and Bamboo admin in for our organization.  We have a around 150 repos and about 500 Bamboo plans.  We have Bamboo and Stash connected with an application link.

Recently I looked at the SSH tab of my own user profile and noticed I had dozens and dozens of SSH keys.  One was for my development machine (which I added long ago), and the rest had a label that is the base URL of our Bamboo instance.  Each of these keys seemed to be different.

Later, I discovered that every time I log into Bamboo and add a new "Repository" to a plan (using the "Stash" repository type and selecting the repo and branch from drop-down lists), it adds another SSH key to my account.

To me, this doesn't make much sense.  I check the account of another admin and they also had a pile of SSH keys with the same label (from the Bamboo plans they had created).

Is this expected behaviour?  It seems really strange to me.  What happens to all these plans if one of the admins leaves the organization?  Why would setting up a Bamboo plan linked to a repository create an SSH entry for the user that created the Bamboo plan?
fields.summary: SSH Keys created for my Stash user profile when adding a repository to a plan based on "Stash" repo type.
